mn146:9.3: ‘While this oil lamp is burning, the oil, the wick, and the flame are all impermanent and perishable.

mn146:9.10: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

mn146:9.16: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.
mn146:9.17: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”

mn146:11.1: Suppose a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver. Without damaging the flesh inside or the hide outside,
mn146:11.2: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments with a sharp meat cleaver,
mn146:11.3: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
mn146:11.4: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’
mn146:11.10: Because even if they wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
mn146:11.11: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before,’
mn146:11.12: still that cow is not joined to that hide.”
mn146:12.1: “I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
mn146:12.3: ‘The inner flesh’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
mn146:12.4: ‘The outer hide’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
mn146:12.5: ‘The connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments’ is a term for greed and relishing.
mn146:12.6: ‘A sharp meat cleaver’ is a term for noble wisdom.
mn146:12.7: And it is that noble wisdom which cuts, carves, severs, and slices the connecting corruption, fetter, and bond.

mn146:15.1: Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn146:15.2: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fourteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people
mn146:15.3: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously not full.
mn146:15.4: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, but they still haven’t got all they wished for.”
mn146:16.1: Then the Buddha said to Nandaka,
mn146:16.2: “Well then, Nandaka, tomorrow you should give those nuns the same advice again.”
mn146:16.4: And the next day he went to those nuns, and all unfolded just like the previous day.
mn146:27.1: Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn146:27.2: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fifteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people
mn146:27.3: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously full.
mn146:27.4: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, and they got all they wished for.
mn146:27.5: Even the last of these five hundred nuns is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
mn146:27.6: That is what the Buddha said.
mn146:27.7: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
